Donnie Darko.Action: Wakes up disoriented but manages to stand and take his bike back up the hill despite hesitation.
Rides his bike confidently through the neighborhood, interacting with locals who smile at him.
Engages in family dinner conversation, attempts light teasing with sister.
Responds to sister's insult with sarcastic comeback about therapy.
Engages in family dinner conversation with sarcastic, somewhat biting remarks, indicating confidence in speaking but lacking social tact.
Responds to his sister's question with a quick, literal answer showing awareness of social contexts (e.g., teasing about age to have children).
Makes a sarcastic comment to Elizabeth about therapy suggesting quick wit but possibly poor emotional intelligence.
Stops taking his prescribed medication without informing family or doctors.
Engages in sarcastic, confrontational language with family members.
Reads literary works indicating intellectual engagement.
Responds to his mother's attempt at connection with hostility and insults her ('Bitch').
Turns off his lamp and isolates himself in the dark, avoiding interaction.
Refuses to engage in conversation or emotional connection with his mother.
Stops engaging in childish pranks like toilet papering houses since sixth grade, indicating some maturity and self-control.
Responds rudely and dismissively to his mother, telling her to take pills and calling her a 'bitch', showing poor social skills and emotional immaturity.
Takes his prescribed medication deliberately, seeming to be aware of his mental health needs, showing some responsibility.
Leans into dark moods and hostile speech rather than communicating effectively with family, indicating emotional instability and lack of interpersonal competence.
Walks down the street alone late at night, appears distant and confused.
Stares nervously at Frank (the figure in the bunny suit) but listens to him.
Does not respond verbally when asked about belief in God and the end of the world, shows vulnerability by holding his stomach and taking deep breaths.
Walks outside late at night to a specific location following a mysterious voice's instructions, showing some initiative and focus.
Responds to the voice and the figure of Frank with confusion, does not question or act confidently on the information.
Holds his stomach and takes deep breaths when confronted with unsettling information, indicating vulnerability and lack of control.
Apologizes to Dr. Fisher after being found sleeping on the golf course, showing responsibility and politeness.
Walks toward his house calmly despite the presence of emergency vehicles and crowd, showing composure but no outward signs of engagement or connection.
Wakes up and quickly responds to authority figures on the golf course, apologizing to Dr. Fisher.
Appears confused and unsure about the meaning of the numbers written on his arm.
Walks through the neighborhood crowd calmly and without causing disturbance despite the chaos around his house.
Asserts his identity calmly to the police officer to gain access.
Looks over at his family and processes the situation quietly, appearing lost in a trance.
Confidently approaches the police officer and asserts his identity, allowing himself access through the barricade.
Seems lost in a trance, staring in awe at the jet engine and appears detached from the situation.
Jokes by threatening to fart in Samantha's face, causing her to threaten to tell their mother.
Engages in childish humor by threatening to fart in Samantha's face.
Appears lost in a trance, not engaging actively with others.
Dodges death, indicating some form of resilience or fortune.
Refuses to discuss his sleepwalking episode with friends, showing reluctance or evasiveness.
Asks about consequences before accepting to smoke, exhibiting cautious thinking.
Defends Cherita against racist remarks by friends, demonstrating social awareness and moral judgment.
Responds thoughtfully to Ms. Pomeroy's question, showing engagement with literature and deeper meaning.
Grins ear to ear and makes eye contact with Gretchen when she sits next to him in class.
Takes Grandma Death's hand and walks her back to her mailbox, opens it for her, smiles and tries to cheer her up.
Asks Eddie detailed questions about the origin of the roof damage, showing curiosity and attention to detail.
Politely helps Grandma Death by holding her hand and opening her mailbox, showing social grace and maturity.
Responds with a thoughtful smile and simple words about mail and tomorrow, indicating emotional intelligence and calmness.
Stands silently and listens to Grandma Death's profound statement without interrupting, showing respect and reflective behavior.
Admits to skipping medication and purposely trying to make his mother feel guilty, psychologically abusing her.
Shares with Dr. Thurman about meeting a new friend and recounts how this friend saved his life.
Admits to psychologically manipulating his mother but is aware of his actions.
Skips medication cycles despite being advised to take them regularly.
Accurately recounts the event of a jet engine falling on his bed and following 'Frank's' instructions, showing awareness of his experience.
Expresses skepticism about the claim that the world is coming to an end, showing critical thinking.
Mentions meeting an imaginary or supernatural friend and believes in impossible events without clear evidence, which may indicate confusion or lack of grounded judgment.
Tells Cherita to go home and be safe

Warns Gretchen to check her backpack because others might steal from her.

Explains the significance of antiseptics with historical reference, showing knowledge and intelligence.
Admits to prior mistakes such as burning down an abandoned house and being held back in school.
Engages thoughtfully and confidently in conversation about future ambitions (painter, writer) and changing things.
Mentions personal difficulties (jail, academic setbacks) without seeming overwhelmed or defeated.
Engages in a sincere and somewhat vulnerable conversation with Gretchen, including asking her to go out with him.
Apologizes when Gretchen calls him weird, showing politeness and sensitivity.
Shares a personal, somewhat innocent observation about soap being the only thing that never gets dirty.
Engages in a playful, philosophical observation about soap being the only thing that can't get dirty, showing abstract thinking.
Successfully initiates a personal conversation and asks Gretchen to go out with him, showing social confidence.
Responds to therapist's questions with evasive or off-topic answers, failing to address the intended topics.
Responds honestly to Dr. Thurman's question about thinking of Alyssa Milano rather than his family; rejects the idea of thinking about his family in a sexual way, calling it sick.
Shows disengagement and detachment by undoing his belt and not paying attention during therapy.
Writes 'They made me do it' repeatedly on the classroom blackboard without hesitation, appearing resigned and possibly seeking to communicate something covertly.
Turns the volume down and focuses his thoughts on a specific subject during school instead of random distractions.

Writes repeatedly on the blackboard without hesitation when asked, showing decisiveness and confidence.
Participates in a casual, friendly activity with peers (shooting bottles and stuffed animals with a BB gun).
Observes Jim Cunningham's 'Controlling Fear' program quietly and attentively.

Uses a gun to shoot bottles and a Smurf doll accurately.
Makes a cynical or dismissive comment about the purpose of life related to reproductive organs, which could reflect a lack of sensitivity or social tact.
Recalls Grandma Death's age and daily routine accurately, showing awareness and memory.
Takes prescribed medication but then puts the pills back in the cabinet after taking them, suggesting confusion or uncertainty about his dosage.
Lies calmly on the couch watching TV, appearing relaxed but possibly disengaged from proactive behavior.

Shares a dark, imaginative statement about delivering children from pain and monsters, revealing a protective intention.

Marks the calendar obsessively and tracks exact time intervals with precision.

Ignores Gretchen's suggestion to leave and remains focused on Jim Cunningham, falling into a paranoid trance.
